Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2018 International Symposium on Distributed Computing (DISC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support student attendance at the 2018 International Symposium on Distributed Computing (DISC), in New Orleans, LA, October 15 to 19, 2018. Distributed computing is ubiquitous, with many applications in the Internet and in small-scale devices. DISC gives an opportunity to expose students to the fundamental concepts behind the algorithms that drive distributed computing applications.

This award will provide partial support to approximately 10 students to attend this top conference in the area of distributed computing. Efforts will be made to support students from under-represented groups and geographic diversity among students will be taken into account. The award will encourage and facilitate the student participation in this top-tier computer science conference. It will contribute towards attracting more under-represented groups to computer science research giving students an opportunity to engage in the important technical, professional, and social exchanges that DISC fosters.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Performance_Institution.Name: Louisiana State University & Agricultural and Mechanical College

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant helped to provide funding for student travel support for attending the 32nd International Symposium on Distributed Computing (DISC) that was held in New Orleans, Louisiana, between October 15-19, 2018. DISC is a premier conference on distributed computing with an emphasis on theoretical foundations of distrubted algorithms which are inspired by real-life applications and state of the art technological advances in distributed systems. This travel grant helped to enhance student participation and broaden the audience of distributed computing to a wider and diverse population. In the DISC conference, all participating students had the opportunity to acquire a holistic idea about many distributed computing concepts, and also respective problems and solution techniques that can be readily applied in practical situations. The selection committee for the travel awards consisted of three faculty members from US institutions. The majority of the students that were supported from this travel grant were mostly from underrepresented groups. These students were exposed to novel concepts that will potentially help them to incorporate ideas from distributed computing in their own research. The impacts of this grant are that it provided the opportunity for students to learn more about the latest technological trends in distributed computing and the related new research directions.
